items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:           Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m.
                                    Receive and Sunshine the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: 
                                    From San Jose  Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO to 
                                    East Side Union High School District
	                                     
	 
The District has received a copy of the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO initial bargaining proposal, a copy of which is attached.  Per the Government Code, the District must receive and sunshine in open session the initial proposal of any bargaining unit prior to commencing negotiations.  Administration recommends that the Board receive, sunshine, and take any public comment on the initial proposal of the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive, sunshine and take any public comment on the initial proposal of the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO.
	 
	 
	 
	 
AFT Local 957
Sunshine Proposal
For the Successor Contract Commencing 7/1/12
May 22, 2012
	 
The San Jose Federation of Teachers, AFT Local 957, presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Union High School District for the successor contract commencing on July 1, 2012. 
	 
The Federation proposes to maintain the existing Collective Bargaining Agreement (which includes the on-going modifications negotiated for 2010-2011 and 2011-2012), and proposes the following changes in the successor agreement:
Article 13000 - Substitution
Article 15000 - Salary
Article 16000 – Employee Benefits
Add a Professional Development article
Further, AFT proposes that this successor agreement encompass a three-year term from July 1, 2012 to June 30, 2015 with agreed-upon annual reopeners.
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, subdivision (d), the Federation reserves the right to amend, modify and supplement this proposal during the course of bargaining.
	 
The Federation looks forward to productive bargaining.

Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA.  The District and the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA reached a tentative agreement on May 15, 2012.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA on May 23, 2012.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board accept any comment on the proposed Tentative Agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2012 – August 31, 2013.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  11.02
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve San Jose Conservation Corps Charter Renewal   (10 minutes)
	 
BACKGROUND
Public Charter Schools are approved initially for up to a five (5) year period and at the end of that time must apply for a charter school renewal for a term of five (5) years and continue to apply for renewal after each five (5) year term. Pursuant to Education Code 47605, a public hearing is required within thirty (30) days following the submission of a renewal charter school petition to the district.  The renewal petition was submitted to the district on April 19, 2012.
	 
During the Public Hearing, the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents. The public hearing was held during the May 10, 2012 meeting where SJCC gave a presentation and had many supporters in attendance.   The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charter renewal within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition. The decision will be made at the June 7, 2012 Board Meeting.
	 
San Jose Conservation Corp is an adult education program that focuses on Vocational Training supported with a high school diploma program. SJCC focuses on recruiting at risk young adults who are high school dropouts. In 2010-11 alone, 45% of their population is on probation or parole, 62% are gang involved, 36% are young parents, and 16% are students with disabilities. This makes SJCC a unique school with a unique population of students. They issued 464 high school diplomas, 213 vocational certificates, 180 students enrolled in community college, and 120 students enrolled in apprenticeship programs. 
	 
A team of district experts from the Instructional Division, Business Division, and Human Resources Division reviewed the charter renewal proposal and visited both SJCC sites. Their findings are included in the renewal matrix. 
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the renewal of San Jose Conservation Corp charter.  The charter will be renewed for 5 years and will expire, June 30, 2017.

SUBJECT:
Approve Incoming Loan Agreement with History San Jose
			 
History San Jose (a non-profit organization) has identified some items of District property that may be of local historical significance.  History San Jose has requested that the District enter into a “incoming loan agreement” with History San Jose whereby the District would loan such items to History San Jose for an initial three (3) year period for display and preservation at and by History San Jose.  Pursuant to the Loan Agreement, History San Jose would be responsible for the preservation and insurance of the District items.  Administration recommends that the Board approve the arrangement.  History San Jose is, at this time, better-suited to care for and preserve the items.  In addition, the Loan Agreement will make the items accessible available for viewing by the larger District and San Jose community in a more appropriate historical context.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attached form of "Incoming Loan Agreement" with History San Jose, subject to review and modification by Legal Counsel, as appropriate, to adequately protect the District's interests.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discuss and/or Approve Program Improvement Year 4 School Alternative Governance Plans
	 
Local Educational Agencies (LEA) who have schools in Program Improvement, Year 4, are responsible for working with the schools to develop a restructuring/alternative governance plan. Oak Grove High School and W. C. Overfelt High School are both in Year 4 and have been working with the district to analyze progress and construct a plan. 
	 
Schools in Program Improvement Year 4 are required to do the following:
Create a District and School Liaison Team (DSLT).  This team leads the school through the PI Year 4 planning process and chooses a restructuring/alternative governance plan. A  DSLT was created at both sites following the state suggested composition, that is, supervisor of the principal, curriculum and instruction administrator, classroom teachers, member of the school’s advisory council, parents, and other informed individuals. Each DSLT met twice and followed the CDE recommended protocol to select appropriate alternative governance option(s) and revise the Single Plan for Student Achievement.
Allow adequate opportunity for teachers and parents to comment before taking action. With assistance from committee members, information was shared and stakeholders had opportunities to comment on suggested plans.
Choose one of the four following options as their restructuring/alternative governance structure. 
Close the school and reopen it as a charter school.
Replace all or most of the school staff (which may include the principal) who are relevant to the failure to make AYP.
Enter into a contract with an entity, such as a private management company with a demonstrated record of effectiveness, to operate the public school.
Implement any other major restructuring of the school’s governance arrangement that makes fundamental reforms and leads to improved student achievement. 
After completing the CDE recommended protocol, Oak Grove and W. C. Overfelt selected D, that is, to implement an alternative governance structure.
	 
Oak Grove’s school plan for alternative governance structure - The main focus areas of their alternative governance structure are as follows:
Restructure professional development to focus on proven instructional strategies using best practices and regularly scheduled teacher/administrator classroom walkthroughs.
Implement both common and formative assessments to better align instruction with pacing guides ensuring all students have equal access to the content standards.
Develop a timely and effective intervention plan to increase student success.
W. C. Overfelt's High School plan for alternative governance structure - The three main focus areas of their alternative governance structure are as follows:
Implement a comprehensive schoolwide professional development plan to focus on two critical items:
Use of data and assessments to inform instruction. 
Implementation of Research Based Instruction in all classrooms
Effectively implement Small Learning Communities schoolwide.
Increase the enrollment and success rates in AP and higher level math and science courses.
Ensure that the school’s Single Plan for Student Achievement reflects the alternative governance structure chosen above.
The alternative governance structure is represented in both Oak Grove’s Single Plan for Student Achievement and W. C. Overfelt’s Single Plan for Student Achievement.
	 
The DSLT will continue to meet on a regular basis at both high schools to look at student achievement data and monitor the alternative governance plan. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION: 
It is recommended that the Governing Board Approve the Alternative Governance Structures at Oak Grove and W. C. Overfelt.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Governing Board Approve the Alternative Governance Structures at Oak Grove and W. C. Overfelt.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discuss and/or Approve LEA Plan
	 
LEAs must develop a single, coordinated, and comprehensive Plan that describes the educational services for all students that can be used to guide implementation of federal and state-funded programs, the allocation of resources, and reporting requirements. The Plan should be periodically reviewed and updated as needed, but at least once each year. The LEA Plan can serve as a summary of all existing state and federal programs and establish a focus for raising the academic performance of all student groups to achieve state academic standards. 
	 
The approval of a Local Educational Agency Plan by the local school board and State Board of Education is a requirement for receiving federal funding subgrants for NCLB programs. The LEA Plan includes specific descriptions and assurances as outlined in the provisions included in NCLB. In essence, LEA Plans describe the actions that LEAs will take to ensure that they meet certain programmatic requirements, including student academic services designed to increase student achievement and performance, coordination of services, needs assessments, consultations, school choice, supplemental services, and others as required. 
	 
The last board approved complete LEA Plan was in 2002. Since that time the district has annually updated the addendum to the LEA Plan, incorporating all Program Improvement recommendations provided by the district outside evaluator as required by law. The state strongly suggests that districts write a new LEA Plan rather than use an Addendum. Following this suggestion, the district, with input from all stakeholders, has written a new LEA Plan based on a updated District Assistance and intervention Report of Findings and Recommendations completed in may 2012 which is included in this board item. Additionally the plan  addresses  Common Core State Standards transition, and our districts focus on college and career readiness for all students. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
	Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
	Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION: 
It is recommended that the board approve the LEA Plan.

SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.

SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading to Amend Board Policies 5127 Graduation Ceremonies and Activities and 6146.1 High School Graduation Requirements
	 
Description:
Commencing with the 2012-2013 school year, completion of a course in Career Technical Education is an alternative to the requirement that a pupil complete a course in visual or performing arts or foreign language.
In accordance with Assembly Bill 1330 the Board may elect this option if it provides parents, teachers, students and the public with specific information at a regular public meeting of the Board regarding the intent to implement a CTE course as an alternative for high school graduation.  The provisions of AB 1330 will be repealed on January 1, 2018, unless its provisions are extended by legislative action.
	 
It is the administration's recommendation that the provisions allowed under AB1330 be extended to students enrolled at an Alternative Education High School.
	 
Definition of CTE
	 
CTE courses that may be substituted for the existing one year-long course requirement in visual or performing arts or foreign language must meet the following definition:
“A course in career technical education” means a course in a district-operated career technical education program that is aligned to the career technical model curriculum standards and framework adopted by the state board, including a course through a regional occupational center or program operated by a county superintendent of schools or pursuant to a joint powers agreement.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the first reading of the revised Graduation Ceremonies and Activities 5127 and High School Graduation Requirement 6146.1.

SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of Proposed Amendments to Board Policy 5131 Students - Conduct and Proposed Board Policy 5131.2 Students - Bullying
		 
		 
Pursuant to new legislation (AB 9 and AB 1156) that becomes effective July 1, 2012, all school districts must have policies in place that prohibit discrimination, intimidation, harassment and bullying based on the actual or perceived characteristics set forth in Sections 422.55 and 220 of the Penal Code, and disability, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, race or ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics.  The policy shall include a statement that the policy applies to all acts related to school activity or school attendance occurring within a school under the jurisdiction of the superintendent of the school district.  Districts shall also adopt a process for receiving and investigating complaints of this nature as well as including bullying prevention strategies in the comprehensive safety plans.
		 
Board Policy 5131 Students – Conduct has been amended to comply with updated legislation.  Information on prevention, intervention and the process for handling complaints of bullying and cyberbullying has been moved to Proposed Board Policy 5131.2 Students – Bullying.  
		 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board accept this First Reading of proposed amendments to Board Policy 5131 Students - Conduct and Proposed Board Policy 5131.2 Students - Bullying.

SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of Proposed Amendments to Board Policy 6163.4 Student Use of Technology and Acceptable Use Policy
	 
	 
Background
Districts must update their Board Policy in compliance with the Children Internet Protection Act (“CIPA”) by June 30, 2012 to address the new cyber-bullying requirements.
	 
The Protecting Children in the 21st Century Act was enacted into law in October, 2008.  Many E-Rate applicants began addressing this law shortly thereafter by putting measures in place to monitor the online activities of minors and provides education about appropriate online behavior and online safety.
	 
The FCC released CIPA rule revisions in August, 2011, incorporating the E-Rate program provisions of the Protection Children in the 21st Century Act.  
	 
To demonstrate compliance districts should:
Update the Internet Safety Policy (not simply the Acceptable Use Policy) to include monitoring the online activities of minors
Must provide for educating minors about inappropriate online behavior, including interacting with other individuals on social networking websites and in chat rooms and cyber-bullying awareness and response

N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board accept this First Reading of proposed amendments to Board Policy 6163.4 Student Use of Technology and Acceptable Use of Policy.

SUBJECT:
Receive, Discussion and/or Action of Preliminary Budget for Fiscal Year 2012-13 with May Revision
			 
			 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2012-13 Preliminary Budget as recommended. This is the second of three presentations of the budget to the Governing Board.  The preliminary budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and cabinet which provide a basis for the final budget.  The preliminary budget presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s FYE 2011-12 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The FY 2011-12 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance. After reviewing the fiscal year end 2011-12 summary, major budget assumptions for developing the 2012-13 budget will be discussed including School Services dartboard, enrollment and ADA, and salaries and benefits.  The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have been announced and are reflected in this second preliminary budget update.  
The preliminary budget presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for the budget year 2012-13 and for the multi-year thru 2014-15 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the district’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the Governing Board’s June 21 meeting.

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

To be determined

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-36 Proposed Use of Tier III Categorical Program Funds (AB189)
			 
			 
Education Code 42605 grants districts flexibility in “Tier III” categorical programs and authorizes districts to use these funds for “any educational purpose, to the extent permitted by federal law.”  For the 2008-09 fiscal year to the 2014-15 fiscal year, inclusive, local educational agencies that use the flexibility provision of this section shall be deemed to be in compliance with the program and funding requirements contained in statutory, regulatory, and provisional language.
			 
As a condition the Governing Board is required, at a regularly scheduled open public hearing, to take testimony from the public, discuss, and approve or disapprove the proposed use of funding and to make explicit the purposes for which the funding will be used. Attached to the resolution is a list of specific programs, the estimated funding amounts, and the proposed activities for which the funds are to be expended.

FROM:

PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Rogelio Ruiz, Legal Counsel
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Extension of Measure G Program Management Agreement
			 
SGI Construction Management, LLC is the Board-approved assignee of Seville Group, Inc. under the original program management agreement.  SGI has served as Program Manager of Measure G since the inception of the Measure G $298,000,000 bond program.  The term of the Program Management agreement was extended by the Board to June 30, 2012.  The Measure G program funds have not yet been fully expended and Measure G projects remain on-going and will remain on-going for at least two additional years, and thus program management services are still needed in connection with Measure G.  Administration now recommends that the Program Management agreement with SGI be extended to and including June 30, 2013, subject to the terms of the attached recommended Third Amendment.
			 
The draft Third Amendment extends the date of the Program Management Agreement by one year (to June 30, 2013) and also modifies the termination provision of the original agreement and now allows the District to terminate the agreement for convenience upon sixty (60) days written notice to SGI without requiring the District to pay SGI’s demobilization expenses or a termination fee as currently provided in the agreement.  This change is intended to avoid any monetary penalties to the District associated with a termination for convenience and to provide the District increased flexibility as the Measure G program winds down and in light of the recently hired District Architect and Project Manager.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Program Management fees and expenses per Agreement
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Third Amendment as presented and extend the Measure G Program Management Agreement with SGI to and including June 30, 2013.

TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal Counsel
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-38 Declaring an Emergency and Authorizing Superintendent or His Designee to Enter into Contracts for the Repair and Remediation of Fire Damage at Evergreen Valley High School
			 
			 
As a result of a fire that occurred at Evergreen Valley High School Campus on Friday June 1, 2012, we are requesting that the Board of Trustees authorize an Emergency Resolution.  The fire was caused by someone unknown to the District who set two fires, one in a small dumpster that contained paper and cardboard for recycling and the other was set in a pile of scrap wood and metal located behind the library.  The fires caused two light fixtures and an alarm box to be damaged on the library building and also extensive smoke and soot damage to the library which has affected every aspect of the building including all of the fixtures and books. Time is of the essence in these kinds of situations. The work needs to proceed immediately as the longer the soot and debris remains in place the more difficult the odor removal process can be and the smoke and soot will have a corrosive effect on the Facility and its contents. The Emergency Resolution enables the District to forgo the normal time frame and processes related to the work on the electrical junction box and the building which has been damaged and to engage a contractor(s) for the repair and remediation work without advertising for or inviting bids.
			 
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Property/Liability
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution 2011/2012-38 declaring an emergency pursuant to Public Contract Code section 1104 and 20113 and authorizing the Superintendent or his designee to enter into contracts for the repair and remediation of the fire damage at Evergreen Valley High School.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution 2011/2012-38 declaring an emergency pursuant to Public Contract Code section 1104 and 20113 and authorizing the Superintendent or his designee to enter into contracts for the repair and remediation of the fire damage at Evergreen Valley High School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  16.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Permanent Course Adoption for Beginning Journalism, Child Development Education, I, II, II, Engineering Design and Development, Film Production, Fire Science I, Guitar Ensemble, History of Globalization, Trade and Finance, Hospitality and Tourism Management, and Studies In Media
	 
	 
The Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed Beginning Journalism, Child Development Education, I, II, II, Engineering Design and Development, Film Production, Fire Science I, Guitar Ensemble, History of Globalization, Trade & Finance, Hospitality and Tourism Management, and Studies In Media courses.  These courses was piloted during the 2011-2012 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.
	 
Beginning Journalism
Beginning Journalism is a yearlong English elective that covers major themes and styles in modern journalism and news reporting, as well as develop an understanding of photo journalism and web journalism.  Students will read and write a variety of articles throughout the year.  In addition, students will have the opportunity to see the application of journalism theory in a real life context by participating in the media journalism department's productions.  As an English elective, students will be expected to complete substantial and frequent amounts of reading and writing.
	 
Child Development and Education I
Child Development and Education I delivers a comprehensive study of the developmental stages of children from conception through early adolescence.  In this yearlong course, students will learn major theories of child development; psychoanalytic theories, behaviorist, social and cognitive theories.  Growth and development will be covered including the physical, emotional and cognitive development of each stage of young children.  Students will research careers in the early childhood field.
	 
Child Development and Education II
Child Development and Education II is a comprehensive study of developmental stages of children from conception through early adolescence.  This is a yearlong course.  In this course, students will continue to learn major theories of child development introduced in Child Development and Education 1, such as; psychoanalytic theories, behaviorist, social and cognitive theories on the influence of heredity and environmental factors.  Focus of these theories will be on infant and toddler development.  Students will research careers in the early childhood field.  In addition, students will learn professional components of childcare facilities including safety procedures and first aid certification.
	 
Child Development and Education III
Child Development and Education III is a comprehensive study of developmental stages of children from conception through early adolescence.  This is a yearlong course.  In this course, students will continue to practice developmentally appropriate teaching competencies under guided supervision.  Students utilize practical classroom experiences to make connections between theory and practice in order to develop professional attributes in a childcare setting.  All aspects of curriculum development and lesson plan implementation are emphasized.  Students will also focus on child centered, play-oriented approaches to teaching, learning and assessment.  Classroom management techniques are discussed.  Student display knowledge of the use of environment, professional development skills, guidance techniques and portfolio documentation for assessment.
	 
Film Production
Film Production is a course designed to develop student proficiency in the performing arts, with film being the area of focus.  Students will practice and refine all of the proficient level California Performing Arts content standards for theater, while simultaneously exploring the ways in which cinematography can influence and enhance theater performance.  Students will participate in a variety of activities related to film production, including acting, directing, scripting, storyboarding, producing, editing, and designing.  Students will engage in extensive analysis and response to films, and will learn both how to effectively critique and how to respond to criticism.  Students will work collaboratively on a regular basis and will develop and follow schedules to meet deadlines.  Students will learn how film and theater are connected to other art forms and careers.  Continuing students will be challenged with advanced projects an high level explorations.
	 
Fire Science I
Fire Science I is a one year long course to career planning with an emphasis on careers and services available in the protective services industry.  The Protective Services Pathway prepares high school students for success in further education and work in entry-level positions in protective services through classroom instruction, hands-on training, and community experience.  Students in this pathway will learn about and practice public safety.  The students will explore careers in fire service and EMT response.  This pathway encompasses career opportunities in a variety of jobs in which the main focus is ensuring the general safety and well-being of the community.
	 
Guitar Ensemble
The Guitar Ensemble is an advanced guitar class.  It is intended for students who have gained a mastery of guitar performance and music theory.  It will provide students who have taken Guitar I and Guitar II a venue in which to practically use their newly acquired guitar skills and to further their music education.
	 
Much like Band and Choir, the Guitar Ensemble will give guitar students the opportunity  to hone and advance their musical skills through performance in an ensemble setting.
	 
History of Globalization
The History of Globalization, Trade and Finance is the study of international trade, finance and its development.  The course focuses on world economic, geographic, historical, social and political issues.  By incorporating current events into the curriculum, students will gain an understanding of the relationship of international trade with world governments and the impact of trade on society and the environment.
	 
Hospitality and Tourism Management
This 11th  grade course will provide the students of the Academy of Hospitality & Tourism the opportunity to learn and apply industry-specific principles of management and entrepreneurship.  Students will learn the necessary skills to be able to start, own, and operate/manage a restaurant.  Students will learn how to plan an effective menu, survey and understand their customer base, choose a site, create a business plan, take care of all of the accounting and financial needs of the business, plan, design and construct a restaurant, sanitation management and dealing with health agencies, daily operations and analysis, customer service, and human resource management, leadership entrepreneurship, customer service, accounting and finance, planning, research, and teamwork/team building.
	 
Studies in Media
By the end of this course, students will be familiar with the importance of oral and written communication as it applies to modern formats of media.  Students will have honed their interpersonal communications with an emphasis on interviewing techniques and human behaviors.  Students will be aware of the legal and ethical issues surrounding the media, and especially the newer issues that develop as the internet and modern media develops.  Students will develop critical and analytical thinking skills through the development of speeches, interviews and papers including journalistic articles, and handson technology application and analysis of the media.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the above courses.
